content.description: A  silly personal challenge to do hard moves on rock (i use the term loosely) that literally falls apart. But the bright side is every time anyone does it they get a FA.
content.protection: TR from Lie Way Back anchors.
content.location: left of "Cup Cakes and Beer", in area of chalky, crumbly rock?

content.description: Climb a bulge right off the ground with a bolt and quartz pebbles. Continue up wind carved pockets and cracks to anchors.
content.location: Just left of "The Crown Jewel of Safe Harbor Climbing, Four Stars, Eleven B"

content.description:
Start left of dihedral. Pull initial roof pinching on sugar cube sized quartz. Continue up fun and featured rock that becomes ever so slightly more than vertical.

 From this anchor you can rappel all the way down to the enola (gravel) trail with a 60M rope

content.protection: TR from Overlap anchors. Need long webbing.

content.description: Climb easy terrain to overhanging arete. Lie back up arete to top and then move right to anchors.
content.location: Just right of The Crown Jewel of Safe Harbor Climbing, Four Stars, Eleven B.

content.description: Climb easy ramp to right side of cliff and hidden bolt. Then up arete trending left to second bolt. Climb cliff face straight up over slight bulge to anchors.

climbs.name: The Crown Jewel of Safe Harbor Climbing, Four Stars, Eleven B

content.description: Climb into small dihedral and the exit left over bulge to a stance. Continue up and left to anchors.
content.protection: 3 bolts with optional slung horn and 2 bolts anchor shared with Pinch the Pebble
content.location: Start in the middle of the cliff at a small dihedral

content.description: This naturally exposed rock sits 50' above the trail. you can see it from the base of entrance route look up and climber's left. To get up there climb entrance route. At first set of anchor's move left 15' to second set of anchors. Bring up second, then set off again up a dirt slope to trees.  Bring up second. From trees walk up around the balcony rock descending on it's north side. This puts you at the base of Overlap.
